Journal.Title: Environmental science and pollution research international

Article.ArticleTitle: Release of phosphorus from sewage sludge during ozonation and removal by magnesium ammonium phosphate.

AbstractText: The release rule of phosphorus from sewage sludge during ozonation and removal by the magnesium ammonium phosphate (MAP) method were investigated. The results showed that the concentrations of total phosphorus in aqueous phase (TP<sub>(A)</sub>) and orthophosphate (PO<sub>4</sub><sup>3-</sup>-P) in ozonized sludge supernatant rose obviously with increasing ozone dose when ozone dose was below 61.2 mg O<sub>3</sub>/gSS then almost kept constant. The TP<sub>(A)</sub> and PO<sub>4</sub><sup>3-</sup>-P contents in the ozonized sludge supernatant were 70.9 and 63.3 mg/L when ozone dose was 61.2 mg O<sub>3</sub>/gSS, respectively. Total phosphorus in the sludge solid (TP<sub>(S)</sub>) was mostly distributed in inorganic phosphorus (IP) (more than 81.5% of TP<sub>(S)</sub>), and non-apatite inorganic phosphorus (NAIP) was the major component of IP in the sludge (more than 78.7% of IP) during ozonation. The release contribution (RC) of IP to TP<sub>(A)</sub> accounted for over 73.9%. The optimized conditions for the removal of phosphorus from ozonized sludge supernatant were set at an initial Mg<sup>2+</sup>/PO<sub>4</sub><sup>3-</sup>-P molar ratio of 1.8, pH 9.5, and reaction time of 5 min, under which the removal efficiencies of TP<sub>(A)</sub> and PO<sub>4</sub><sup>3-</sup>-P were 43.1 and 52.2%, respectively.
